posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14584518
>How the fuck did Prajeeet drop the ball so hard?
Unironically, Gandhi

India is a cautionary tale as to what happens when spoilt, out of touch, rich kids dabbling in communism actually get hold of a country. Gandhi's family were part of the upper nobility of one of the princely states, and his father had been Prime Minister to the Raj of Porbandar. Gandhi was educated at British universities. He wasn't an actual Hindu holy man, he was another overprivileged, ivory tower philosopher larping as the proletariat.

Gandhi's ideas about economics can broadly be categorized as anarcho-communism. He didn't want to do away with industrialism entirely but he wanted the basic unit of the Indian economy to be the village women and their looms. It's why there's a spinning wheel on the Indian flag. Like every dictator-in-waiting he proposed an autarky, where the Indian people would live a simple, agrarian life rather than participating in global capitalism. He and his follows founded a number of communes which were meant to be a model for India's economy going forward.

After independence the new ruling class tried to put some of these basic principles into practice, and although his economic ideas were never really followed completely it did lead to a heavily socialist-leaning economic model. It was a bit closer to the centralized Soviet system than Gandhi had envisaged, but it did include subsidies for the traditional cottage industries that Gandhi loved. The predictable result of this was decades of stagnation, which only ended with economic liberalization in the 1990s.

tl;dr Gandhi's ideas about economics robbed India of over forty years of economic growth. If you count all the Indians who died unnecessarily of malnutrition and disease, Gandhi probably killed more people than Pol Pot.

The majorian system in question is a leftover from the days when US was not a centralized federation, but a collection of republics, all of which wanted representation. Also, they all were west coast states, meaning that they had more or less similar population. The contrast wasn't nearly as severe as Ohio vs California for example. That changed after the american civil war, when new legislations were put in place to make such conflicts never happen again. There's also the fact that the southern states were forced to abolish slavery against their will, something you can't do without a reformed, more centralized government.

Can't speak for the other things though, I'm not an expert on US's judicial system.

Maybe, but the Washington Naval Convention soured that. The American and British navies were allowed to be 5:3 to Japanese, meaning for every 3 Japanese warships the Americans and Brits had 10 combined. The Americans and British clearly wanted to control Japan and treat them as a junior partner - which, back then, wasn't something Great Powers do or did and Japan clearly wanted to be a Great Power. After what happened with European colonial powers in China, the Japanese were naturally distrustful of losing any military might that could allow them to resist. The Americans wanted a weak Japan because they both had interests in dominating the Pacific, and the British wanted to secure India, Hong Kong, and their East Asian trade routes - in their minds, a weak Japan was the way to do it but the Japanese had no interest in being delegated to Middle Power status by 2 Great Powers who humiliated China and could easily do the same to Japan.

>any response to my so-called refutation of free will is "cope" and "pilpul" because... it JUST IS, okay?!

Let's get this out of the way. "Free will" in the sense that man possesses causal agency over his own actions is, of course, immediately evident to any sane, rational person. The very existence of alternative choices when determining our course of action is proof enough.

If however, you mean "free will" to mean that man's volitional faculty is unbounded by any constraints and influences, then that is patently false. Man is not autonomous in the way that God is; what He wills always comes to pass, whereas what we will may change or be obstructed by some obstacle (physical handicap, mental unpreparedness, lack of financial resources, etc.)

The point in Exodus is that Pharaoh's hardness of heart is a direct outworking of God's decree. As He said in Exodus 9:16 "For this very purpose I have raised you up, so that I might show My power in you, and that My name might be declared in all the earth." Does that absolve Pharaoh of guilt? Not at all, for He knew the will of God (to let the Hebrews go) as spoken by Moses, but suppressed the reality of YHWH's sovereignty as a result of his unbelief. God gave Pharaoh over to his stubbornness so as to multiply the wonderful works of His mighty deliverance for Israel's sake, that they might believe in Him.

The long and short of it is that simply because God is the ultimate cause of all things in the final sense does not make void the reality of secondary or efficient causes that He has established per His providential decree.

Do you have any other questions, anon?

What exactly is meant in the Heart Sutra when it says that all Dharmas are empty? What exactly does empty mean in this context

Does it mean that they are factually untrue?
Does it mean that they are unreliable because they are impermanent?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14585907
It means the dhamma are empty of sbhava, or self-nature. There is not separate "thingness" to them, they are as empty as everything else is in this regard.

>Does it mean that they are unreliable because they are impermanent?
Things are not unreliable nor reliable because of their impermanence. They simply are impermanent, as they have no bhava.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14585925
I appologize if these are very simplistic question, but can you elaborate more on what Bhava means in this case?

Can you compare it to concepts in other religions? What might some other religions claim has self-nature?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14585941
Let me put it this way, in a common allegory.

If you are walking and you come across an orange tree in an orchard, and you look at the tree, you think "This is an orange tree, it's existence is as this orange tree." Yet, if you one by one remove all things from the tree that are not the "thingness" of the orange tree, you will eventually be left with no tree to speak of.
Remove the sun, remove the water, remove the soil, remove the actions of the orchard husbandman, remove the consciousness of yourself, remove the air, remove the cells and atoms of the tree, and so on.
You can continue to strip away everything that is not the orange tree, and you will never find the "thingness" of the orange tree, it's bhava.

This is because the orange tree is full of the sun, and full of the air, and full of the water, and full of the orchard husbandman, and yes, even full of your own consciousness. Yet, the orange tree is empty of being an orange tree.
That is why emptiness, or sunyata, is also fullness. Empty of self-nature, full of the whole cosmos.
It's also called Indra's Net.

In Hinduism(depending on the school, of course), the "atman" is the "real self" that exists eternally and unchangingly.
In Abrahamic, there is the soul.

Plato claimed that forms (in Sanksrit "rupa) have real existence, a real thingness. Buddha denied this possibility of rupa having bhava.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14586029
There is no "thing" that reincarnates. Rebirth and reincarnation are generally seen as difference. In rebirth, there is only karmas, and mind states arising from phenomena.
It's why Buddha remained silent when asked:

"After death, does Tathagata(Buddha Gotama) exist, not exist, both exist and does not exist, neither exist nor does not exist?"
To answer affirmative or negative to any of these questions would lead to a wrong view of things, and thus to distress and confusion.

You may well ask, "What spiritual part of me wakes up in the morning?" You as you are now in this very moment have no self-nature ultimately. Only a "provisional self" that arises from phenomena and mental states depending on those phenomena (often called consciousness, or less confusingly, cognization).
As there is no "real self" that incarnates from moment to moment, there is no "real self" that incarnates from life to life.

Thus, there is no fear of dissolution or destruction (annihilationism), or fear of eternal sufferings (eternalism). Because there is nothing existing there in the first place to suffer nor to be destroyed.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14586296
RNA is self-replicating due to its chemical structure. The 1st RNA created the 2nd RNA, the 3rd RNA, etc. You know how you said its a 99.999% copy? Well, some of these new RNA disintegrated, some lived on. Then one of these new RNA rearranged itself to get a new add on (think a computer installing a graphics card to play games). Well, RNA with this new add on disintegrated less than the RNA without this new add on. And what was the name of this new add on? DNA. So, the RNA with this DNA add on kept replicating itself, until this RNA with DNA said "fuck it. i want more power" so they installed more add ons: ribosomes and plasma. And just like that, this new upgraded RNA is now what we call "bacteria". Bacteria: "MORE POWER!" Boom, the mitochondria. Well, these new Bacteria with mitochondria cant be called bacteria anymore, so we'll give it a new name: Eukaryotes. These Eukaryotes kept replicating itself indefinitely until one day the Eukaryote said, "im tired of being a 1 man team. How about I work together with other Eukaryotes to form something greater". And what was the thing they formed? Plants.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14586610
K36 is what you should use most of the time.

The numbers next to the names symbolize admixture proportions and the "Distance:" part refers to genetic distance.
>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_distance

So basically the calculator shows you what ancestry proportion you're genetically closest to, or rather you have the smallest genetic distance to. So even if you're something like a "100%" Russian, there's still within-population genetic variation which is made up of archaic groups.

You're 44.2% Baltic_EST, which refers to an ancient Baltic population. The HUN appears to be ancient Hungarian, etc. You'll have to look up what the reference tags actually mean, they're usually based off a singular DNA sample.

>>14583698
The Mambila shields, of the Mambila people from the Mambila Plateau in the Nigeria/Cameroon border region are in my opinion, hands down, one of the coolest shield-types in African history...

"Mambila shields (kor) are (or were) woven from a reed or sedge and were used in warfare both between Mambila villages and with raiders from outside such as the Fulani/FulBe who raided the Mambila Plateau for slaves in the late C19th and (contentiously) the Chamba before them.

That they survive today is because they have been collected over the last century by travellers and missionaries etc (many of which are now in museums) AND (more importantly) because they are have a role in the Nggwun dance. This is a war dance which in some Cameroonian Mambila villages is closely connected to the installation of Chiefs, and is repeated on a regular basis at which time the Chief repeats his oath of office, and swears (among other things) not to abuse his poisition."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
silver hilted “seme”, East Africa.

The “seme”, “simi”, “ol alem”, or “lion’s sword”, is traditionally associated with the Maasai and Kikuyu, but is also used by a number of regional peoples such as the Samburu, Kipsigis, Mbeere and Arusha. Weapons of a broadly similar type are found in a wide belt of Eastern Africa from Lake Victoria in the west to the Swahili coast in the east

The seme can vary in length, from the size of a knife, to the size of medium length sword, with an elegant leaf shaped blade flaring towards the tip and featuring a median ridge running the length of the blade. Typically, this one handed slashing weapon has a short wooden hilt covered in leather, often tapering towards the tip, and is kept in a leather sheath, often dyed red.
The seme was used for mundane everyday purposes like clearing brush and butchering meat, and was also used for war, and during lion hunts, which were once important rites of passage. It is important however to note, that the seme is a secondary weapon, second only to the spear.

Among the Maasai, men belong to age groups that determine their status, with each age group being assigned a distinctive set of weapons. At about 15 to 21 years of age, Maasai youths, called “layok”, are initiated into the status of young manhood, called “moran”, at which point they are given their first seme, which they will carry for the rest of their lives.
The Maasai and Samburu have their own subgroup of specialized blacksmiths, known as “Ilkunono”, who produce seme’s, and who were traditionally surrounded by taboos and even scorned for being ritually unclean. These Nilotic speaking peoples have also depended heavily on the traditional blacksmiths of the Kikuyu and other regional Bantu speaking peoples for the production of their seme’s and other iron weapons and tools.

Maybe ironically (?) the Communist Party of China was birthed by resentment at China getting screwed during the Versailles negotiations which left Chinese ports in the hands of various foreign powers (I think Japan had one port maybe, but I don't remember the details). So it was like a mix of that but also the influence rolling in from Russia after the October Revolution.

People tend to focus on Mao but they gloss over the early period after its founding in 1921 when a whole different crew was running it and Chiang Kai Shek had a lot of those guys killed. Marxism-Leninism has anti-imperialism built into the ideology from the start, so it meshed with these young intellectuals who were radicalizing to the far left during this period. Mao was actually a fairly liberal / anarchistic / democratic-ish type person originally. Then the communists merged with this class war in the countryside against landlords who were really more like feudal lords or plantation lords, like if the U.S. was more like the Confederacy and the British, French and Spanish controlled different port cities along the coast.

I don't, but it's entirely possible that it exists, because the claim is designed to be impossible to disprove. The teapot by definition has no effect on anything and is unobservable. But it's not logically inconceivable. It's possible in the same way that "the universe started last Tuesday" is possible. I can't say with 100% certainty that it's false, because that certainty is impossible to have. But sinse it changes nothing whether it exists or not, it's not even worth caring about if it's true. So you can disregard it freely.

You can also believe in the teapot if you want. No good reason to believe in it, but it's possible. I changed my mind, I believe the undetectable teapot exists just as a way for the universe to fuck with us. The funniest reality is the one where it exists just to mess with Bertrand Russell. Jesus, Son of God and God Himself in Human Form, died a very painful death on the Cross after being beaten, lashed, with thorns on his head and a heavy cross on his back. And for all the pain and suffering he endured, he still managed to be sort of "happy", in the sense he didn't become totally angry and bitter, and when he appears after his resurrection he bares only the scars of the stigmata but none of the actual pain of the event.

He had his moment of asking God why He had forsaken him, because he had doubt and confusion, but he pushed past that and remained himself. He asked for God to forgive Mankind, and he looked at the thief being crucified beside him and promised him a spot in Heaven. Jesus did not let the pain undo him.

So what we can understand from this is that our Human suffering is inconsequential. It is not "suffering" to get a paper cut. It is not "suffering" to lose a hand. It is not "suffering" to lose your life. These things happen to all people in varying degrees. We are all mortal, and we will all die. Our mortality is not painful. But, experiencing bodily or psychological anguish and then letting it change who you are as a person... letting it unravel you and make you into someone full of wrath and other sins... that would be "pain" and "suffering". And that is a result of our free will.

What is our Earthly "pain" but a little splinter in our spiritual finger, when compared against an eternity in a Heaven without evil?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm inclined to say Britain. It's strange to think because of how the USA was founded, and its initial hostility toward Britain, yet over time the US and Britain became close trading partners, and eventually staunch military allies, and this close relationship has only grown stronger and closer since the mid 19th century when it began. Since WW2, both Britain and the US both consider the other their "most important trade partner" and move in effective lockstep unity on the UN security council.

The other contender is France, which has ostensibly been a US ally since the Revolution, and is majorly responsible for the Revolution succeeding in the first place. However nominally affable the relationship, France has not always been an agreeable or close ally with America. Particularly since WW2, they've become increasingly standoffish and uncooperative, though never crossing the line into being unapproachable.

So it's a choice between Britain and the US going from enemies, to rivals, to allies, to best chums, vs the often aloof, borderline estranged friendship of some 250 years with France.

US-France relations soured pretty badly after WW2, despite the high opinion of America held by many French people for its role in liberating the country from the Nazis. France resented Americans not wanting to share nuclear technology with them and resented being subordinate to American command in NATO and having to host US military bases, and resented being told to give up their colonial possessions. So in 1966 De Gaul pulled France out of NATO's unified command structure and kicked out all the NATO troops stationed there. >>14583023
At the Nuremberg trials, it was established that "just following orders" is a valid defense, but only below the rank of lieutenant, and only if the orders in question are not clearly illegal. Many times the accused said that they followed orders because it was either work in the camps or the front line.

In a subversion, the Nazis who gave birth to this idea weren't the ones who were Just Following Orders but the ones who impressed their superiors enough with their enthusiasm to be assigned to running concentration camps. The ones who were just following orders ended up at the Russian Front and usually didn't survive to reach Nuremberg in the first place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Some historians who have interviewed ex-Nazis, or supporters or collaborators of the regime, have reported that the subjects are very often proud of what was done and either don't use this defence or only used it as an excuse if they don't want to attract bad attention. Notably, some of those same historians have also interviewed former Soviet and Japanese soldiers who also took part in atrocities and generally conclude that this trope suits them better since in the former case you could be sent to the Gulag or shot if you were suspected of being "un-revolutionary", and in the latter case one's superiors savagely beating their subordinates and treating them like dirt was the rule rather than the exception. In contrast, while in some cases not following orders could get you sent to the very dangerous Eastern Front, the majority of SS and Wehrmacht soldiers were often not severely punished and very usually had no problem with what they were doing; indeed, in many, many cases, they exceeded their orders and many atrocities were initiated at ground-level by officers. Since conquered Jews, Poles and other victims were forbidden to work (slave labour aside) yet were now part of the Greater German Reich, they became an economic burden, and since deportation was increasingly impractical, mass murder was often seen as cheaper and easier. The majority of Holocaust victims were shot, in thousands of separate instances; roughly half of its millions of victims were dead before Auschwitz opened its gas chambers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: As it happens, Adolf Hitler hated giving orders and liked to keep them as vague as possible, leading to what historian Ian Kershaw called "working towards the Fuhrer", i.e. "doing what you think Hitler wants", which as it happens was usually just "anything that made the problem go away". A common problem, even in the early days of the regime, was that the SA, the SS, and the more ideological members of the Party and the army would assault or kill more people than the leaders intended and had to be reined in (this was one of the reasons the SA was purged on Night of the Long Knives, as they were considered too unruly compared to the "disciplined" SS). The initial plan for the occupation of Poland — then Eastern Europe — was to kill a certain percentage of various Polish social groups (e.g. Jews, academics, officers, lawyers, etc.) and have the rest either deported or kept as slave labour (and/or held as hostages) while their land would be given to "ethnic" Germans, but the SS and sections of the German army ended up killing so much that even Himmler protested to Hitler (albeit on the grounds that it showed a lack of discipline). Eventually, for many, committing genocide simply became normal.

To my knowledge, every single native american culture regarded itself as having always existed in the Americas.

There were many migrations at many different times, these must have been hugely significant events for the cultures involved. Why didn't any histories survive (afaik) which recount a migration of some kind to this new land?

Why weren't the histories remembered in some way? Of course it's worth considering that virtually everybody died recently, and so only a fraction of oral histories which existed hundreds of years ago would even have a chance of survival.

Furthermore, it seems to me that certain oral traditions are memorized from one generation to the next--- how long does it take for even these to decay and change? Why does that seem to happen so quickly?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14584248
Anthropologists who have studied living cultures with oral traditions found that the tribal story teller will make shit up and change the story on the spot to make whatever point he wants to make, and over time oral traditions become degraded quite quickly--with a deviation of around 30% of the story, even per telling of the same story by the same story teller. This explains why within 50 years of Jesus' death there were so many differences (~30%) between even the synoptic gospels despite there being literate greeks/romans and jews around. It is very unlikely over 1000 years that more than a few threads of the story is original without a written tradition, unless the culture in question is unlike the ones we observe now and had a strong cultural focus on dogmatic recitation and preservation of the original story.
